t: Job 30
“But*pn now they laugh at me, men*ld who are younger than I, whose*ln fathers I would have disdained to*ld set with the dogs of my flock.
What*ln could I gain from the strength of their hands, men*ld whose vigor is gone?
Through*ln want and hard hunger they*ld gnaw the dry ground by night in waste and desolation;
they*ln pick saltwort and the leaves of bushes, and*ld the roots of the broom tree for their food.
They*ln are driven out from human company; they*ld shout after them as after a thief.
In*ln the gullies of the torrents they must dwell, in*ld holes of the earth and of the rocks.
Among*ln the bushes they bray; under*ld the nettles they huddle together.
A*ln senseless, a nameless brood, they*ld have been whipped out of the land.
“And*pn now I have become their song; I*ld am a byword to them.
They*ln abhor me; they keep aloof from me; they*ld do not hesitate to spit at the sight of me.
Because*ln God has loosed my cord and humbled me, they*ld have cast off restraint in my presence.
On*ln my right hand the rabble rise; they*ld push away my feet; they*ld cast up against me their ways of destruction.
They*ln break up my path; they*ld promote my calamity; they*ld need no one to help them.
As*ln through a wide breach they come; amid*ld the crash they roll on.
Terrors*ln are turned upon me; my*ld honor is pursued as by the wind, and*ld my prosperity has passed away like a cloud.
“And*pn now my soul is poured out within me; days*ld of affliction have taken hold of me.
The*ln night racks my bones, and*ld the pain that gnaws me takes no rest.
With*ln great force my garment is disfigured; it*ld binds me about like the collar of my tunic.
God*ln has cast me into the mire, and*ld I have become like dust and ashes.
I*ln cry to you for help and you do not answer me; I*ld stand, and you only look at me.
You*ln have turned cruel to me; with*ld the might of your hand you persecute me.
You*ln lift me up on the wind; you make me ride on it, and*ld you toss me about in the roar of the storm.
For*ln I know that you will bring me to death and*ld to the house appointed for all living.
“Yet*pn does not one in a heap of ruins stretch out his hand, and*ld in his disaster cry for help?
Did*ln not I weep for him whose day was hard? Was*ld not my soul grieved for the needy?
But*ln when I hoped for good, evil came, and*ld when I waited for light, darkness came.
My*ln inward parts are in turmoil and never still; days*ld of affliction come to meet me.
I*ln go about darkened, but not by the sun; I*ld stand up in the assembly and cry for help.
I*ln am a brother of jackals and*ld a companion of ostriches.
My*ln skin turns black and falls from me, and*ld my bones burn with heat.
My*ln lyre is turned to mourning, and*ld my pipe to the voice of those who weep.
